title: Ticket #6923: Python Bindings: streamlined submit semantics
description:
When you condor_submit from the command line, you don't need to explicitly provide a schedd or transaction if you don't want to. So why do you need to from the bindings?

This ticket changes the signatures of Submit.queue and Submit.queue_with_itemdata so that all of the arguments are keyword arguments, changes the meaning of one of the existing arguments, and adds a new optional argument. The argument ordering is the same, so this will not break existing users.

Semantics change of old argument: txn (transaction) will be now be optional. If it is None, a Transaction will be created and used internally. if a Transaction is given, it is used to submit the job, just like it is now.

New optional argument: schedd. If None, submits to the local Schedd.

txn and schedd cannot both be non-=None=, because if you have a Transaction you should just pass it in. If they are both passed, we throw a ValueError.

Combined, this means you don't need to do the "get a Schedd, get a Transaction, then submit" rigmarole if you're doing what most users do: submit to the local schedd. You just create your Submit and queue it, which mirrors the behavior on the command line (create a submit file, then submit it).

All of this will be implemented via pure-Python wrappers over the existing C++ bindings code. No changes are necessary to the underlying bindings.
remarks:
2019-Feb-20 20:33:12 by bbockelm:
> When you condor_submit from the command line, you don't need to explicitly provide a schedd or transaction if you don't want to. So why do you need to from the bindings?

Because the transaction model - and the relation between submission and the proxy object (the Schedd) - is very important?

The analogy is teaching someone about SQL without teaching them about transactions. Sure, your SQL client probably has an autocommit mode, but at some point the concept of a transaction is pretty important to the model.

So, I see this as "help people get going to the point they realize you simplified away a core concept they need to know".

With that in mind, still think the approach is correct here?

2019-Feb-20 20:41:39 by karpel:
> So, I see this as "help people get going to the point they realize you simplified away a core concept they need to know".

I am unconvinced that most users ever need to know about transactions at all.

Admins should, but admins will be digging deeper into the API anyway.

2019-Feb-20 20:50:22 by bbockelm:
> I am unconvinced that most users ever need to know about transactions at all.

I think that's still compatible with my analogy and statement. The majority of DB users are a-OK with autocommit mode, hence the fact its default in most (all?) SQL clients I am aware of!

However, it's still a core concept!

Hence my question is whether there should be some explicit space put between the "streamlined" mode and the existing syntax.

Another case to pull from is libcurl, whose C API has an "easy" mode -- and the corresponding function names are all called easy_*. Should this be submit or easy_submit? A class method or a module-level method?

2019-Feb-20 21:57:14 by karpel:
I guess that, as a user, I don't consider submitting jobs without a transaction to be "unsafe" in the same way that autocommiting partial changes to a DB is, because (at least from my perspective) a single queue command is atomic.

I think a better analogy from DB-world would be that this aims to be the equivalent of making a blog post through your Wordpress web interface instead of writing the text and metadata into the DB yourself. Power-users and admins might need that for maximum whatever, but most people just want to get their blog post up.

An example from Python-world would be how Requests' sessions work (http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/advanced/#session-objects). You create a Session and then make multiple requests from it, as if it were the main library API.

They let you shoot yourself in the foot by doing a lot of requests to the same place without making a Session, but it is the first major "advanced" topic, and I imagine if you google "help my requests are slow", the first thing you'll find is that.

It seems like the equivalent for us would be being able to do Schedd.submit(submit_obj), or do txn = Schedd.transaction(); txn.submit(submit_obj). But it seems that the bindings have been moving away from that kind of API.

2019-Feb-20 22:55:32 by bbockelm:
> I don't consider submitting jobs without a transaction to be "unsafe" in the same way that autocommiting partial changes to a DB is

I don't see autocommit as unsafe: rather, it's a significant simplification.

In terms of the bindings -- what about a module-level function of htcondor.submit? htcondor.ez_submit?

2019-Feb-21 14:37:45 by karpel:
Abandoned in favor of #6926
